title: What Does it Really Mean to Have Different Kinds of Infinities?
body: Can someone explain to me how there can be different kinds of infinities? I was reading "The man who loved only numbers" by Paul Hoffman and came across the concept of countable and uncountable infinities, but they're only words to me. Any help would be appreciated.

title: List of interesting math podcasts?
body: mathfactor is one I listen to.  Does anyone else have a recommendation?

title: How can you prove that the square root of two is irrational?
body: I have read a few proofs that [MATH]\\sqrt{2}[/MATH] is irrational. I have never, however, been able to really grasp what they were talking about. Is there a simplified proof that [MATH]\\sqrt{2}[/MATH] is irrational?

title: What is your favorite online graphing tool?
body: I'm looking for a nice, quick online graphing tool. The ability to link to, or embed the output would be handy, too.

title: How are we able to calculate specific numbers in the Fibonacci Sequence?
body: I was reading up on the Fibonacci Sequence,  [MATH]\\text {{1,1,2,3,5,8,13,....}}[/MATH] when I've noticed some were able to calculate specific numbers. So far I've only figured out creating an array and counting to the value, which is incredibly simple, but I reckon I can't find any formula for calculating a Fibonacci number based on it's position. Is there a way to do this? If so, how are we able to apply these formulas to arrays?

title: Is it true that [MATH]0.999999999\\dots=1[/MATH]?
body: I'm told by smart people that [MATH]0.999999999\\dots=1[/MATH] and I believe them, but is there a proof that explains why this is?

title: How do you calculate the semi-minor axis of an ellipsoid?
body: Given the semi-major axis and a flattening factor, is it possible to calculate the semi-minor axis?

title: What is a real number (also rational, decimal, integer, natural, cardinal, ordinal...)?
body: In mathematics, there seem to be a lot of different types of numbers. What exactly are:  Real numbers Integers Rational numbers Decimals Complex numbers Natural numbers Cardinals Ordinals  And as workmad3 points out, some more advanced types of numbers (I'd never heard of)  Hyper-reals Quaternions Imaginary numbers  Are there any other types of classifications of a number I missed?

title: Why is the matrix-defined Cross Product of two 3D vectors always orthogonal?
body: By matrix-defined, I mean [MATH]\\left<a,b,c\\right>\\times\\left<d,e,f\\right> = \\left|     \\begin{array}{ccc}  i & j & k\\\\  a & b & c\\\\  d & e & f  \\end{array}    \\right|[/MATH] ...instead of the definition of the product of the magnitudes multiplied by the sign of their angle, in the direction orthogonal) If I try cross producting two vectors with no [MATH]k[/MATH] component, I get one with only [MATH]k[/MATH], which is expected. But why? As has been pointed out, I am asking why the algebraic definition lines up with the geometric definition.
latex: \left<a,b,c\right>\times\left<d,e,f\right> = \left|     \begin{array}{ccc}  i & j & k\\  a & b & c\\  d & e & f  \end{array}    \right|

title: Can you recommend a decent online or software calculator?
body: I'm looking for an online or software calculator that can show me the history of items I typed in, much like an expensive Ti calculator.  Can you recommend any?
